Circles.Definition: Represent the number of times the radius goes around the circle
A line that cuts through exactly half of the circle.

Quadrilaterals.Definition: A quadrilateral is a polygon in Euclidean plane geometry with four edges and four vertices. Other names for quadrilateral include: quadrangle - tetragon and 4-gon.

Rectangle. Opposite sides are parallel and equal.
Square. Opposite sides are parallel and all sides are equal. 
Parallelogram. Opposite sides are parallel and equal.
Rhombus. All sides are equal and opposite sides are parallel. 
Trapezium.
Kite.

Opposite Sides: Parallel and ≅
Adjacent Sides: Not always ≅ and never Parallel 
Angles: Opposite angles ≅ and adjacent angles Supplementary
Diagonals: Bisect Each-other
 Area: b * h

Opposite Sides: | | and ≅
Adjacent Sides: ≅
Angles: Opposite angles ≅ and adjacent angles Supplementary
Diagonals: Bisect each-other and ⊥
 Area: b * h or 1/2(d1 * d2)

Opposite Sides: | | and ≅
Adjacent Sides: ≅
Angles: All 90° and ≅
Diagonals: Bisect each-other and  ⊥ and  ≅
 Area: b*h or lw or s^2 s=sides

Opposite Sides: | | and ≅
Adjacent Sides: Different if not a square
Angles: All 90° and ≅
Diagonals: Bisect each-other and  ≅
A square can be a rectangle but a rectangle can not be a square.
 Area: l * w or b * h

Opposite Sides: 1 set | | and 1 set  ≅
Adjacent Sides: Different
Angles: Base ∠'s are ≅
Diagonals:  ≅
Area: (b1+b2)/2 * h

Opposite Sides: Different
Adjacent Sides: 2 pairs of consecutive ≅ sides
Angles: 1 pair of opposite angles are ≅
Diagonals: ⊥
Area: 1/2(d1*d2)

Special Signs.Definition:
Congruent --> ≅
Parallel --> | |
Degrees --> number°
Perpendicular -->  ⊥ 
Angle --> m∠ABC the m stands for measurement. 
Sine --> Sin
Cosine --> Cos
Tangent --> Tan
Triangle --> Δ
Similar --> ~
Pi --> π
Rounds to --> ≈
Inequalities --> ≤ or ≥ or < or >
Multiply --> ⋅
Exponent --> a^b 
Percent --> %

Angles.Definition: Adjacent angles are connected and share a ray in between them.
adjacent angles that add up to 180°.
Opposite angles that are equal to each other which is called Vertical Angles.
A ray that cuts an angle in half making to equal parts.
angles between 2 lines and on opposite sides of a transversal
Angles that lie outside a pair of lines and on opposite sides of a transversal.
Lie on the same side of the transversal and in corresponding positions
Angles that are on the same side inside the lines
exterior angles that lie on the same side of the transversal.
A quantity is congruent (equal) to itself. a = a
if a=b then a can be substituted for b in any equation.
the point that is equidistant from each vertex.
Connects all of the midpoints of the inside of a regular polygon.
distance from the center to any vertex
The distance from center to the median of the side of the regular polygon.
Connects the vertices of a regular polygon.

Basics of Geometry.Definition:
A line is a straight path that continues in both
directions forever. Lines are one-dimensional.
A plane is a flat, two-dimensional object. It has no thickness and extends forever.
A line segment is a portion of a line located between two points.
A ray is piece of a line that starts at one point and extends infinitely in one direction.
An angle is formed by two rays with the same endpoint
The point where the rays meet is called the vertex.
Parallel lines are two lines on the same plane that do not intersect.
Perpendicular lines are two intersecting lines that form a 90° angle.
If three points A, B, C are collinear and B is between A and C, then AB+BC = AC
A postulate is a statement that we take to be automatically true. We do not need to prove that a postulate is true because it is something we assume to be true.
A ratio compares two numbers. A 1:1 ratio is stated as, or can also be written as 1 to 1
If a point is on the perpendicular bisector of a segment. Then it is equidistant from the endpoints of the segment. The converse of this theorem is also true.

A segment bisector is a line segment or ray that passes
through another segment and cuts it into two congruent parts.

Perspective.Definition: Perspective is a narrator's interpretations of events, people, and places based on his or her own personal experiences and background. The narrator's dialogue with the reader reflects these aspects, and may present opinions or different ideas than other characters in the story
A first-person narrative is a mode of storytelling or a peripheral narrator in which a storyteller recounts events from their own point of view using the first person i.e. 'I' or 'we' etc.

Second person point of view uses the pronoun 'you' to address the reader. This narrative voice implies that the reader is either the protagonist or a character in the story and the events are happening to them
In third-person point of view, the author is narrating a story about the characters, referring to them by name, or using the third-person pronouns 'he,' 'she,' and 'they.'

Third person limited differs from omniscient third person because the narrator is an active participant. Although the pronouns may be the same as in omniscient POV, the narrator only knows what a single person or group (the viewpoint narrator or current narrator) knows.

THIRD-PERSON OMNISCIENT NARRATION: This is a common form of third-person narration in which the teller of the tale, who often appears to speak with the voice of the author himself, assumes an omniscient (all-knowing) perspective on the story being told

natural selection.Definition: the process whereby organisms better adapted to their environment tend to survive and produce more offspring. The theory of its action was first fully expounded by Charles Darwin and is now believed to be the main process that brings about evolution.
Variation, Overproduction, Adaptation, descent with modification

•    Sometimes, a disaster, such as a disease, can kill many individuals in a population.
•    Just by chance, the smaller, leftover population’s gene pool can be different from the original population’s.
•    The bottleneck effect is a change in gene frequency following a dramatic reduction of a population’s size.
•    The bottleneck effect usually results in a population with reduced genetic diversity.

•Genetic drift can also occur when only a few individuals colonize a brand new habitat.
•    These founding individuals may carry alleles that differ than those from the main population that they came from.
•    The new gene pool therefore stars out with different frequencies and grows in size.
•    When a small group of founding individuals colonize a new location, reduced genetic diversity usually occurs.

Manifest Destiny.Definition: A belief shared by many Americans in the mid 1800s that the United States should expand across the continent to the Pacific Ocean
Mountain Men were explorers and fur trappers who lived in the Rocky mts Opened up trails to the west (Great Plains, Rocky’s, Pacific Ocean
A meeting arranged at a specific spot at a specific time
Trail from Missouri to Santa Fe, New Mexico. All the pathways to the west started in Missouri
From Independence, MO, to Oregon Terr. (about 2,000 mi) Wheat grew, sunshine, fat pigs

Thomas Jefferson.Definition: Thomas Jefferson served as the third President of the United States from 1801 to 1809. Among other things, he was the principal author of the Declaration of Independence, facilitated the Louisiana Purchase which nearly doubled the size of America, abolished the slave trade and founded the University of Virginia. He was a Democratic-Republican and lowered the National Debt significantly.
